examples: strong/high winds

a light wind
a north/south/east/west wind
westerly/easterly winds

gusty/howling winds

in the wind The trees were swaying in the wind.

The wind is getting up (= starting to blow strongly).
The wind has dropped (= stopped blowing strongly).
wind speed/direction
renewable energies like solar and wind power

Let's shelter out of the wind.
Let's wait until the wind drops before setting sail.

There wasn't a breath of wind in the still air.
They set sail the next morning with a fair wind.

We were sailing into the wind.

wind gusts of up to 70 mph

meanings.def: air that you swallow with food or drink; gas that is produced in your stomach or intestines that makes you feel uncomfortable
examples: I can't eat beans—they give me wind.
Try to bring the baby's wind up.

meanings.def: breath that you need when you do exercise or blow into a musical instrument
examples: I need time to get my wind back after that run.
He kicked Gomez in the stomach, knocking the wind out of him.

meanings.def: the group of musical instruments in an orchestra that produce sounds when you blow into them, especially woodwind instruments; the musicians who play those instruments
examples: music for wind and strings
The wind section played beautifully.
a wind band

meanings.def: to release gas from your bowels through your anus
a wind blowing in the same direction as a ship or other vehicle that helps it move faster
examples: With a generous following wind, we sped across the lake.
(figurative) With a bit of luck and a following wind, the project will be completed on schedule.

meanings.def: to hear about something secret or private
examples: She didn’t want reporters getting wind of their plans.

meanings.def: to become/be frightened about something
about to happen soon, although you do not know exactly how or when
examples: Once again, changes are in the wind.

meanings.def: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
very quickly
examples: We ran like the wind.

meanings.def: to make somebody frightened
examples: Tell him that the police have been informed—that’ll put the wind up him.

meanings.def: to take a risk by doing something that is dangerous or that may be illegal
to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do
a small sign of what might happen in the future
to make somebody suddenly less confident or angry, especially when you do or say something that they do not expect
examples: When I agreed to his suggestion at once, it really took the wind out of his sails.

meanings.def: to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks
examples: He threw caution to the wind and dived into the water after the child.

meanings.def: an event or a series of events that has started to happen and will cause important changes or results
examples: A wind of change was blowing through the banking world.

meanings.def: to make somebody unable to breathe easily for a short time
examples: be winded (by something) He was momentarily winded by the blow to his stomach.

meanings.def: to gently hit or rub a baby’s back to make it burp (= release gas from its stomach through its mouth)
an act of turning, wrapping or twisting something around itself or in a circle
examples: Give the handle another couple of winds.

meanings.def: to have many bends and twists
examples: wind + adv./prep. The path wound down to the beach.
A wooden staircase winds up to the attic.
The king's funeral procession wound slowly through city.
wind its way + adv./prep. The river winds its way between two meadows.

meanings.def: to wrap or twist something around itself or something else
examples: He wound the wool into a ball.
Wind the bandage around your finger.
He wound the bandage tightly around his ankle.
They wind individual strands of fibre together to make home-made rope.

meanings.def: to operate a tape, film, etc. so that it moves nearer to its ending or starting position
examples: wind something forward/back He wound the tape back to the beginning.
wind forward/back Wind forward to the bit where they discover the body.
wind something (on) With these cameras, after you click the shutter, you have to wind the film on.

meanings.def: to make a clock or a machine work by turning a knob, handle, etc. several times; to be able to be made to work in this way
examples: wind something (up) He had forgotten to wind his watch.
wind up It was one of those old-fashioned gramophones that winds up.

meanings.def: to turn a handle several times
examples: You operate the trapdoor by winding this handle.

meanings.def: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to wind her parents around her little finger.

idioms.idiom: wind/twist/wrap somebody around your little finger
